chapter: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is not true regarding obstetric cholestasis?

options.c: Pruritus usually develops in the third trimester

questions.explanation:
Obstetric cholestasis is a condition in which cholestasis occurs in pregnancy. Serum bilirubin 
increases very late in the disease and total plasma concentrations rarely exceed 5 mg/dL. Hyperbilirubinemia results from the retention of conjugated pigment. It is also referred to as recurrent jaundice of pregnancy, cholestatic hepatosis, and icterus 
gravidarum. There is a significant genetic influence. It may be more common in multifetal 
pregnancies. Patients present with pruritus that develops usually during the third trimester, typically involving 
the palms and soles. It is worse at night. Icterus may also be present. 541

questions.question:
Question 2: A woman at 34 weeks of gestation presents with severe itching over her palms and soles for 2 
weeks. She gives a history of similar complaints in her last pregnancy. On examination, she is 
icteric. Which of the following is the preferred investigation to diagnose this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of cholestasis in pregnancy. Serum bile acid is the earliest 
and most consistent parameter to increase in obstetric cholestasis. Serum cholic acid is preferred compared to serum chenodeoxycholic acid. Although serum bile acid increases after meals it is still considered an important investigation 
among women with obstetric cholestasis. This is because serum bile acid levels remain 
significantly elevated in women with obstetric cholestasis in comparison to pregnant women 
without it.
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question:
Question 3: A food critic at 32 weeks of gestation presents with nausea and mild right upper abdominal 
pain. She also gives a history of itching over palms and soles for 2 weeks. On examination, 
she is icteric. Investigations done are shown below. What is the preferred treatment in this 
condition?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of obstetric cholestasis. Ursodeoxycholic acid is the drug of choice 
in obstetric cholestasis. It relieves pruritus, lowers bile acid and serum enzyme levels (like SGOT, ALP). It may also reduce 
certain neonatal complications such as preterm birth, fetal distress, and respiratory distress 
syndrome. Antihistamines and topical emollients may provide some relief. Cholestyramine causes decreased absorption of fat-soluble vitamins, which leads to vitamin K 
deficiency. Fetal coagulopathy may develop, which may lead to intracranial hemorrhage and 
stillbirth, and therefore it is not preferred. Bilirubin (mg/d

Question 4: 533 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following features are not likely to be seen in a patient with acute fatty liver of 
pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
542 
Sold by @itachibot Hyperglycemia, hypercholesterolemia, and thrombocytosis are not likely to be seen in acute fatty 
liver of pregnancy (AFLP). Clinical features of AFLP include: • Persistent nausea and vomiting • Progressive jaundice • Hypoglycemia • Hypertension • Proteinuria • Edema • Thrombocytopenia • Moderate to severe liver dysfunction - manifested by: • Hypofibrinogenemia • Hypoalbuminemia • Hypocholesterolemia • Prolonged clotting time.

questions.question:
Question 5: A woman at 37 weeks of gestation with icterus, nausea, and yellowish discoloration of urine 
has abnormal liver function tests. She is suspected to have acute fatty liver of pregnancy. 
Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

options.d: Occurs due to heterozygous defect for fatty acid oxidation

questions.explanation:
Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP) is more commonly associated with male fetuses and not 
female fetuses. AFLP is a rare, potentially fatal complication also known as acute fatty metamorphosis or acute 
yellow atrophy. It is more common in the third trimester. It is due to a defect in the 
long-chain-3-hydroxy acyl-CoA-dehydrogenase (LCHAD) pathway. It is also associated with: • First pregnancy - uncommon in subsequent pregnancies • Maternal obesity • Multiple pregnancies Investigations: • Liver function tests such as AST, ALT, and serum bilirubin levels are raised. • Hemolysis with coagulopathy: • Decreased platelets and fibrinogen • Elevated d-dimers and prothrombin time • Biopsy reveals a characteristic microvesicular fatty infiltration. The definitive management of AFLP is rapid delivery of the fetus and supportive care. Hepatic 
dysfunction usually normalizes within a week of delivery. 543 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 6: Which of the following will not increase the risk for urinary tract infection in pregnant 
women?
questions.explanation: Hypertension is not a risk factor for urinary infections in pregnancy. Risk factors for urinary infections in pregnancy include: • Urinary retention • Vesicoureteric reflux of pregnancy • Diabetes in pregnancy • Sickle cell anemia
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question:
Question 7: A G3P2 lady at 13 weeks of gestation presented for a regular antenatal checkup. A urine 
routine revealed the presence of 2,00,000 gram-negative bacilli/mL. Repeat urinalysis 
showed the following results. Which of the following is not true about this condition?

options.a: Incidence is similar to that in non pregnant women
options.b: It is higher in people with sickle cell trait
options.c: Antibiotic therapy is required only if symptoms develop
options.d: There is risk of developing chronic renal lesions

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of asymptomatic bacteriuria. Antibiotic therapy should be 
given regardless of the symptoms. Asymptomatic bacteriuria refers to persistent, actively multiplying bacteria within the urinary 
tract in asymptomatic women. Organisms that cause urinary infections are those from the normal perineal flora. The most 
common causative agent is E.coli. Others include Klebsiella, and Proteus. Incidence is similar to that in non-pregnant women. Prevalence depends on parity (more in higher 
parity), race, socioeconomic status (more in low SES). It is more common in patients with sickle cell anemia/trait, diabetes. There is a high risk of 
developing chronic renal lesions in later life. It is also associated with: • Hypertension • Anemia • Premature labor • Intrauterine growth retardation • Urinary tract abnormalities in recurrent cases. Diagnostic criteria: • A positive bacterial count of the same species - over 1,00,000/mL • Organisms in midstream clean-catch specimen of urine on two occasions • No symptoms of urinary infection Treatment: • Single-dose therapy - Amoxicillin 3g, Nitrofurantoin 200mg • Regular 10-14 days therapy - Amoxicillin, Nitrofurantoin, Cephalexin, or Amoxiclav 544 
Sold by @itachibot • Recurrent cases need to be treated until delivery with prophylactic doses.
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question:
Question 8: A woman presented to the clinic with severe lower abdominal pain and dysuria at 28 weeks of 
gestation. Suprapubic tenderness was noted on palpation. Urine examination revealed pyuria 
with microscopic hematuria. All of the following can be used to treat this condition except?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cystitis. Ciprofloxacin, a fluoroquinolone antibiotic, is 
contraindicated in pregnancy as it causes cartilage and bone defects in the fetus. Antibiotics are used for treating cystitis in pregnancy. Antibiotics safe in pregnancy include: • Penicillin group • Cephalosporins • Erythromycin • Metronidazole (except in the 1st trimester) Antibiotics unsafe in pregnancy include: • Tetracycline • Aminoglycoside • Chloramphenicol • Metronidazole(in the first trimester) • Fluoroquinolones
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question: Question 9: Which stage of pregnancy is most often complicated by acute pyelonephritis?
questions.explanation:
Acute pyelonephritis in pregnancy most often complicates 2nd trimester of pregnancy. Acute pyelonephritis occurs more commonly in those with preexisting renal disease. It is caused 
by E. coli >> Streptococcus sp., S.aureus > Enterobacter, Klebsiella sp. Clinical features include: • Fever with chills • Loin pain • Vomiting • Right-sided renal angle tenderness Patients may develop acute respiratory distress syndrome due to endotoxin-mediated alveolar 
injury. Hemolysis can also occur due to endotoxins, leading to anemia. Treatment includes intravenous fluids with antibiotics.
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following statements is true about toxoplasmosis in pregnancy?

options.a: Maximum transmission and damage in 1st trimester
options.b: Maximum transmission in 1st trimester and maximum damage in 3rd trimester
options.c: Maximum damage in 1st trimester and maximum transmission in 3rd trimester
options.d: Maximum transmission and damage in 3rd trimester

questions.explanation:
Toxoplasmosis causes maximal complications in 1st trimester and is maximally transmitted in the 
3rd trimester. This is because the risk of transmission increases and the risk of damage decreases as pregnancy 
progresses further. Clinical features of affected neonates include: • Hydrocephalus or microcephaly • Chorioretinitis • Intracranial calcifications • Convulsions • Low birthweight • Hepatosplenomegaly • Jaundice • Anemia
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question:
Question 12: A woman presents for a regular antenatal check-up at 12 weeks of gestation. She works at a 
rescue center that held an adoption drive for cats a few weeks ago. On examination, mild 
cervical lymphadenopathy is noted. Sabin-Feldman dye test is positive. Which of the 
following will be used to treat this condition?
questions.explanation:
546 
Sold by @itachibot The given scenario points to a diagnosis of maternal toxoplasmosis. It is treated using spiramycin. Pyrimethamine-sulfonamide is used when fetal infections are confirmed. It should be avoided in 
the first trimester. Toxoplasmosis is caused by Toxoplasma gondii. Cats are definitive hosts. It can be transmitted to 
humans either by ingestion of raw or inadequately cooked infected meat or by ingestion of oocysts 
via exposure to cat litter or soil. Acute infection is diagnosed either by the presence of IgG and IgM antibodies or by a four-fold 
increase in paired specimens 4 weeks apart.
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question:
Question 13: A per-vaginal examination performed on a lady in labor reveals multiple painful tiny vesicular 
ulcers over the vulva and vaginal walls. A slide showing the microscopic findings is given 
below. What is the best step in the management of delivery in this patient?

options.c: Give tocolytics and treat the infection

questions.explanation:
Painful genital ulcers and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy are suggestive of herpes virus 
infection. The cytological image showing multinucleate giant cells, Tzanck cells confirms the 
diagnosis of HSV. The best step in the management of delivery in this patient is a cesarean 
section. Herpes infection in the newborn may occur during birth, particularly if the mother has genital 
lesions due to HSV-2. In such cases, a cesarean section may prevent neonatal infection.
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question:
Question 14: In a pregnant woman with herpes simplex infection, the risk of transmission to the fetus will 
be maximum during which stage of the pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
The maximum risk of HSV transmission from mother to child is during labor. This is due to the 
shedding of the virus from an active infection in the genital tract during delivery. HSV is a sexually transmitted infection. There is a higher risk of transmission during primary 
infections than with recurrences. Reactivations are less severe. Cesarean delivery reduces the risk of vertical transmission during labor and is indicated in: 547 
Sold by @itachibot • Cases of active genital lesions - both primary and recurrent • Prodromal symptoms - like vulval itching or burning Suspicious lesions should be sent for PCR testing or culture. Antiviral treatment with acyclovir 
should be given if found positive. Women without active genital lesions, without symptoms, or those with active lesions in 
non-genital areas can undergo normal labor and delivery. Management of HSV infection during pregnancy: • Primary or recurrent infections during pregnancy - Oral acyclovir or valacyclovir • Severe or disseminated infection - IV acyclovir followed by oral acyclovir • Pain relief - Oral analgesics or topical anesthetics • Urinary retention - catheterization.
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question:
Question 15: The risk of fetal varicella syndrome is maximum when the mother is infected between  
.
questions.explanation:
The risk of developing fetal varicella syndrome (congenital varicella syndrome) is highest when 
the mother develops varicella infection between 13 to 20 weeks. Congenital varicella syndrome occurs in 2% of infants with maternal varicella between 13 and 20 
weeks of gestation and in 0.4% of infants before 13 weeks of gestation. It is rare after 20 weeks. Congenital varicella syndrome is characterized by cicatricial skin scarring in a zoster-like pattern 
(zig-zag scarring), and limb hypoplasia (shown below). They can also present with neurological 
abnormalities (microcephaly, cortical atrophy, mental retardation), ophthalmic features 
(chorioretinitis, microphthalmia, cataract), and renal and autonomic system abnormalities 
(hydronephrosis, neurogenic bladder). Low birth weight is also common. Infants born to mothers with varicella in the period from 5 days prior to delivery up to 2 days 
after delivery are at high risk for severe neonatal varicella. They acquire the infection 
transplacentally. Since the mother has not developed a strong antibody response, the infant lacks the protective 
effect of maternal anti-varicella-zoster virus (VZV) antibodies. Therefore varicella-zoster immune 
globulin (VZIG) should be administered as soon as possible after birth to newborns whose 
mothers have varicella 5 days before and up to 2 days after the delivery. Since perinatally acquired varicella can be potentially life-threatening, the infant should typically 
be treated with intravenous acyclovir (10 mg/kg every 8 hours) when lesions appear. For pregnant women with uncomplicated primary varicella or herpes zoster that does not require 
hospitalization, the recommended treatment is oral acyclovir (800 mg five times daily for seven 
days). 548 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 16: A young woman delivered a baby with limb hypoplasia and cicatricial skin lesions. Which of 
the following infections did the mother most likely have during her pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of congenital varicella syndrome. It is seen in babies born to 
mothers who had chickenpox infections during their pregnancy. Features of congenital varicella syndrome include: • Chorioretinitis • Limb hypoplasia • Cicatricial skin lesions • Microphthalmia • Cerebral cortical atrophy • Growth restriction • Hydronephrosis The image below shows limb hypoplasia in fetal varicella syndrome: 549 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 17: In a pregnant woman with syphilis, the infection can get transmitted to the fetus during 
which stage in pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
A pregnant woman with syphilis can transmit T. pallidum to the fetus at 10–15 weeks of gestation. Features of congenital syphilis include: • Hutchinson's triad - It is seen in late congenital syphilis. • Hutchinson’s teeth - small widely spaced, peg-shaped, notched upper incisors • Interstitial keratitis • Sensorineural hearing loss • Mulberry molars • Rhagades - deep fissuring of mucocutaneous junctions in the nares, lips, and anus • Frontal bossing • Saber shins - anterior tibial bowing • Clutton’s joints - painless, symmetric hydrarthrosis of the knees and elbows The image below shows Hutchinson incisors. 550 
Sold by @itachibot Note: The risk of fetal infection during untreated early maternal syphilis is ~75–95%, decreasing 
to ~35% for maternal syphilis of >2 years duration.
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question:
Question 18: You are posted in the labor room. While inspecting the placenta to rule out any 
abnormalities, you notice that it appears pale and enlarged. Which of the following infections 
does the mother most likely have?
questions.explanation: Enlarged and pale placenta is due to infection by syphilis. Other clinical manifestations and complications include: • Spontaneous abortion • Stillbirth • Non-immune hydrops • Intrauterine growth restriction • Perinatal death.
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question:
Question 19: A sexually active woman presents with amenorrhea for the past 3 months and a history of a 
painless genital ulcer. UPT is positive and routine antenatal tests revealed a reactive VDRL 
report. What is the dose of benzathine penicillin that should be given for this patient?

options.b: 2.4 million units intramuscularly as a single injection
options.c: 2.4 million units intramuscularly daily, plus probenecid 500 mg orally for 14 days
options.d: 2.4 million units intramuscularly weekly for three doses

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of early syphilis in a pregnant woman. 2.4 million units of 
benzathine penicillin should be given intramuscularly as a single injection. Treatment of syphilis includes: • Early syphilis - Benzathine penicillin G, 2.4 million units intramuscularly as a single injection • Late syphilis (>1 year duration) - Benzathine penicillin G, 2.4 million units intramuscularly 
weekly for three doses Treatment of neurosyphilis: • Aqueous crystalline penicillin G, 3–4 million units intravenously every 4 hours for 10–14 days 551 
Sold by @itachibot • Procaine penicillin, 2.4 million units intramuscularly daily, plus probenecid 500 mg orally four 
times daily, both for 10–14 days.
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question:
Question 20: A woman at 24 weeks of gestation presented with complaints of fatigue, joint pain, and the 
following rash for 3 weeks. Urinalysis showed proteinuria and anti-Smith antibodies were 
positive. Which of the following complications is least likely in this patient? 538 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The above scenario points to a diagnosis of SLE. Preterm labor is a complication in pregnant 
women with SLE, not post-term delivery. Complications in a pregnant patient with SLE include: • Thrombophilia • Preterm labor • Hypertension, eclampsia, and preeclampsia • Anemia • Thrombocytopenia • Stroke • Renal failure Features of neonatal lupus include: • Cardiac abnormalities - Complete heart blocks • Cutaneous lupus • Hepatobiliary diseases - liver failure, transient conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, transient 
transaminase elevations • Hematologic abnormalities - thrombocytopenia, neutropenia, or anemia
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question:
Question 21: A woman with HIV presents for a routine antenatal checkup at 35 weeks of gestation. 
Investigations revealed a viral load of >1000 copies/ml. What will be the best mode of 
delivery in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Cesarean delivery is the preferred mode of delivery in a woman with HIV viral load above 1000 
copies/ml at 34-36 weeks of gestation. Cesarean delivery is usually scheduled at 38 weeks of gestation, or two weeks before the due date. Pregnant women with HIV on ART throughout pregnancy, with a viral load <1000 
copies/mL evaluated within 4-6 weeks of delivery, may choose to have a vaginal delivery.
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question:
Question 22: A woman is diagnosed to be positive for HIV in her first trimester. What is the appropriate 
management?

options.a: Start ART immediately and continue till 6 weeks after delivery
options.b: Start ART after 1st trimester and continue life-long
options.c: Start ART immediately and continue life-long
options.d: Start ART after 1st trimester and continue till 6 weeks after delivery

questions.explanation:
ART should be initiated immediately and continued lifelong in all pregnant and breastfeeding 
women with HIV. This is regardless of their WHO clinical stage and CD4 cell count. *Note: Pearl attached below has been updated according to the NACO ART guidelines 2021. 
Efavirenz has been replaced by Dolutegravir as per the new guidelines. 552 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question:
Question 23: A woman with HIV on antiretroviral therapy is in labor. Which of the following will be given 
to her newborn baby prophylactically?

options.c: 12 weeks of zidovudine, nevirapine and lamivudine

questions.explanation:
In India, according to the NACO guidelines, nevirapine is given in the syrup form for 6 weeks to 
an infant of a mother who is on long-term ART. In infants born to mothers with HIV who are not on ART, syrup nevirapine should be continued 
for 12 weeks. According to the NIH guidelines, zidovudine should be given to the neonate for 4 weeks.
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question:
Question 24: The risk of developing a stroke is highest during what period of gestation in a pregnant 
woman?
questions.explanation:
The highest incidence of stroke in pregnancy is 5 days to 2 weeks postpartum. This is followed by 
the intrapartum period. There is an increased risk of cerebrovascular thrombosis post-delivery due to a sudden reduction 
in the blood volume, a fall in the level of circulating antithrombotic factors, and venous stasis. Risk factors of stroke in pregnancy include: • Hypertensive disorders • Gestational diabetes • Antepartum hemorrhage • Cesarean delivery.
questions.chapter_heading: Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy

questions.question: Question 25: Which of the following is false regarding epilepsy in pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Untreated epilepsy has no association with fetal malformations. Anti-epileptic medications such 
as valproate, phenytoin, etc., are responsible for fetal malformations. Seizure frequency is unchanged in 50%, increased in 30%, and decreased in 20% women. Seizure risk increases during labor as pain and hyperventilation decrease the seizure threshold. The ideal contraceptive in a breastfeeding mother with a seizure disorder is depot 
medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA), as progestins increase the seizure threshold. 553 
Sold by @itachibot Disorders of Menstruation
